lines: While you are pulling out of a parking lot, you witness a hit-and-run accident -- a young boy on a bicycle has been struck by another motorist and is bleeding in the middle of the street. It doesn't look like there is enough time for you
There is not enough time for this. The boy dies.
The panic numbs you to everything except the boy. Your reactions become automatic.
You are not in good shape physically. As you run toward the boy, your heart is pounding through your chest.
You are in good shape physically. The boy is still in the street. You must decide whether to try to help him there or drag him to the safety of the walk.

This was a good idea. Moving him might have meant complications, especially if there were broken bones. The sound of your voice is comforting; the boy is relieved that you are there. You apply pressure to the bleeding. Soon an ambulance
arrives. You are credited with saving the boy's life.
The next day, newspaper and television reports chronicle your heroic deed. You are quite a remarkable person.
It is not a good idea to try to move an injured person. The injuries become complicated. The boy dies in your arms.
Your calmness fails to arouse anyone to the boy's aid. He perishes.
Calmness is a trait that is central to your personality. In this instance you use it to react quickly and efficiently. You approach the boy, who is bleeding profusely.
The kind of coolness this situation requires is not in your personality. Instead of acting calmly, you expend energy trying to keep yourself calm and neglect the situation at hand.
Eventually, the panic overwhelms you. You cannot concentrate on saving the boy. He dies.
